title: Cynthia Erivo admits she was ‘hurt’ by backlash over Harriet role
text:
Cynthia’s casting as Harriet was initially controversial (Picture: AP; Focus Features)

Cynthia Erivo landed the role of a lifetime playing iconic civil rights activist Harriet Tubman, so it’s no surprise the actress admits she was incredibly ‘hurt’ over the backlash she received for simply being cast in the role.

The British actress currently stars as the titular character in Harriet, the heartwrenching biopic from director Kasi Lemons, which charts the activist’s escape from slavery in the 1800s before helping others free themselves from their masters with help from the Underground Railroad safehouses.

But when Harriet was confirmed for the lead role last year, many in the US were upset that an African-American hadn’t been cast.

Recalling her feelings at the time, Cynthia told Metro.co.uk: ‘At first I was hurt because I’m human.

‘But I understand where it’s coming from because I feel like it’s coming from a lack – we don’t get roles like this very often, roles like this don’t come along as often as they should, I’m hoping they’ll start to come along more often now.’

She reasoned: ‘There’s a feeling of ownership over it and once it’s gone, it feels like it will never come again.’

It was no random choice that Cynthia, 32, was trusted to take on the coveted role. The actress is just one letter away from getting the full EGOT, having already won Emmy, Grammy and Tony awards for her outstanding performance in The Color Purple.

Cynthia was left ‘raw’ after filming harrowing scenes in Harriet (Picture: Focus Features)

She’s hopeful that Harriet will continue to open doors for other monumental black figures in history to have their stories told in Hollywood.

‘I hope that this just means there are more stories about her that will be told, we have 101 stories about Abraham Lincoln and stories about Margaret Thatcher and all these other stories about people in history,’ she explained.

‘There should be loads of stories told about Harriet. I’m hoping that one, people give it the benefit of the doubt and see the film and trust that I can do the job and do the work I’m supposed to do.

‘Because I think that’s the thing that confused me the most. I know my job is to tell the story first and foremost, and not necessarily stories that are specifically about me.

‘My job is to play the character and tell the truth of them.’

Cynthia’s performance in Harriet is truly harrowing and has already earned rave reviews from critics before its official release, and the actress would be happy to see Harriet’s story told again on the silver screen.

But more importantly, Cynthia hopes it ‘validates why [she] was cast’ and ‘stills some fear’.

‘I hope it calms any doubts that people are having. That people can trust that I was put there for a reason and it wasn’t a frivolous one and that I never would have taken it if I didn’t think I was up to the challenge,’ she said.

‘And even if the reviews were terrible and even if people didn’t think I was good, I still think the benefit of the doubt is helpful. So I’m hoping that that will at least give people cause to have the benefit of the doubt.

‘And secondly, I hope that people will tell the story over and over again, in different ways and different formats and different places. That’s what the initial feeling was and then I sort of had understanding and then resolution.’

Cynthia has earned applause for her performance in Harriet (Picture: Getty Images)

Harriet’s story isn’t for the faint-hearted – not only did she miraculously managed to escape from her slave master alone, but she went on to rescue hundreds of others who were enslaved.

But there’s one scene in particular that Cynthia will never forget.

** SPOILER **

‘Probably the scene with John Tubman where she finds out that he has married another woman – painful. It was really painful. You have to really find the place where you know what heartbreak is like,’ Cynthia admits.

‘I know what it feels like and you have to go back to that place and then add on the fact that she had run another hundred miles to be there and it just was painful.’

She added: ‘We had worked on that for a few hours that day so by the end of it, I was raw. There was nothing there. That was a tough and challenging yet rewarding scene because it was still one of my favourite scenes – it was tough but still my favourite. It was about womanhood.’

Cynthia is released in UK cinemas on 22 November.
